text: In July 2019, the United States Department of Agriculture issued a newsletter on the proposed new rules for the Supplementary Nutrition Assistance Programme, commonly known as food stamps. The release of the proposed rule "would correct the gap that has widened the reach of SNAP recipients in some states to include people who receive assistance when they do not clearly need it." What exactly does that mean? Thus, Glenn Grothman, President of the United States Republic, R. Glenboola, framed the plan when he supported the plan in an article on 2 October 2019 in the newspaper Milwaukee Journal Sentinel: "Many people didn't know that the millionaire was eligible for food stamps," he said. "I'm glad Donald Trump came and decided to put an end to it." The article indicated that some 40,000 people in Wisconsin would lose food benefits under the proposed changes. The State will also have to improve its computer systems, retrain workers and make other changes that will cost millions of dollars annually. But let's go back to Grootman and his claim. Is he right that a millionaire is eligible for food stamps? Let's take a look. How the program operates according to the article of the Sentinel newspaper: About 40 million people, including some 644,000 Wisconsin residents, received food stamps in 2018. Like most states, Wisconsin provides food benefits to persons eligible for other government programmes without further testing of income and assets. The proposed rule would prevent people in other programmes from automatically qualifying for food stamps. Reviews of their income and assets are required to ensure that, in most cases, their income is at the federal poverty level or less than 130 per cent and that they do not have liquid assets in excess of $2,250. The poverty rate in the three-member family is 130 per cent of the federal poverty level at approximately $2,250 per month. At the national level, the proposal is expected to save $2.5 billion and reduce benefits to about 3 million people. As stated in the article of the Sentinel: In Wisconsin, some 39,600 people in about 24,100 households will lose more than $11 million a year, according to estimates by the State Ministry of Health Services. Of these, some 13,000 are children and about 11,000 are elderly. So, where does the millionaire come from? The back door, apparently.
